div.p: The process and effect of perceiving or sensing states of body or mind; to be distinguished from perceiving a particular sense object, and also from being aware of perceiving, being aware of knowing, or, possibly, awareness of awareness (Boisvert 1995, 51-76; Engel 2009, 109-118, 269-270; Schmithausen 1987, 58ff, passim; Vetter 2000, 22-24, 90-93).

The term designates the 2nd of the five aggregates (skandhas) and the 7th causal link (nidāna) in the canonical list of 12 such links in the pratītyasamutpāda formula. It can be used also in its more general sense of feeling or sensation, pleasant or unpleasant, or in its restricted connotation of “painful sensations, feelings of pain” — which is rather common, and may reflect a general extension of the semantic field as well as a specifically ascetic (Buddhist and non-Buddhist) understanding of the nature of feelings generally. In its function as the 2nd objet of smṛtyupasthāna, vedanā, appears to denote meaning .

A canonical explanation of vedanā as the second skandha offers an etymological definition: SN III.86-87 (3. Khand. 1.8.7.79) Kiñca, bhikkhave, vedanaṃ vadetha? Vedayatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā ‘vedanā’ti vuccati. Kiñca vedayati? Sukhampi vedayati, dukkhampi vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedayati. Vedayatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā ‘vedanā’ti vuccati. “Why, monks, is it called sensation? It senses, monks, therefore it is called ‘sensation’. What does it sense? It senses what is pleasant, and what is unpleasant, as well as what is neither pleasant not unpleasant. It senses, monks, therefore it is called ‘sensation’.”

In the pratītyasamutpāda vedanā is defined in relation to, and distinction from the preceding and the following causal links (sparśa and tṛṣṇā respectively): AvinS 10 sparśapratyayā vedanā | vedanā katamā? ṣaḍ vedanākāyāḥ | cakṣuḥsaṃsparśajā vedanā sukhā duḥkhā aduḥkhāsukhā ca | evaṃ śrotraghrāṇajihvākāyamanaḥsaṃsparśajā vedanā sukhā duḥkhā aduḥkhāsukhā ca | iyam ucyate vedanā || “Sensations arise in dependence on contact. What is sensation? It is the six types of sensation. Sensation born from eye-contact is either pleasant, or painful, or neither painful nor pleasant. In the same way, sensation born from ear, nose, tongue, body o mental contact is either pleasant, or painful, or neither painful nor pleasant. This is called ‘sensation’.”

The term appears to have essentially the same meaning in both usages and : AvinN 99 atra ca pratītyasamutpāde . . . saptāṅgāni vastusvabhāvāni vijñānanāmarūpaṣaḍāyatanasparśa-vedanājātijarāmaraṇākhyāni kleśakarmahetutvāt / “And in this case of dependent arising, . . . seven constitutive elements, because they are causes of affliction and of action, are inherently objective entities, namely: recognition, name and form, the six sense bases, contact, sensation, birth, old age, and death.” AvinN 120 vedanāsaṃjñetyādi / sukhādyanubhāvo vedanā / nimittodgrahaṇaṃ saṃjñā / “‘Sensations, ideation and so forth’: sensations is the experience of something pleasant, etc., ideation is the act of appropriating the distinguishing marks [of the object].”

and AvinN 126-128 vedanā vaktavyā / tadantaramuktatvād ityāha —sparśapratyayā vedaneti / sparśapratyayā vedanetyuktam / vedanā ca trividheti / katamā vedanā sparśapratyayā ’sminn abhipretety āha —ṣaḍ vedanākāyā iti / katame ṣaṭ? ity āha / cakṣuḥsaṃsparśajā yāvan manaḥsaṃsparśajeti / etena tatkālavineyānāṃ prabhedamātrasandehād vedanāyāḥ prabheda eva darśito na tu svabhāva iti / svabhāvasyoktatvāt / vyākhyātam cakṣuḥ pratītya rūpāṇi cotpadyate cakṣuvijñānam / eṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ samaṃ nipātaḥ sannipātaḥ / tato jātā cakṣuḥsaṃsparśajā vedanā {SN II.72} / sā ca tridhā / sukheti sātā / indriyamahābhūtānugrāhiketi yo ’rthaḥ / duḥkhety asātā mahābhūtopaghātikety arthaḥ / “Sensation is explained next, immediately following the words ‘sensation depends on contact’. It is stated, ‘sensation depends on contact, and sensation is of three kinds.’ If one asks, ‘What sort of sensation conditioned by contact is meant here?’ the reply is that it refers to the six groups of sensations. And to the question of which six, the reply is the type born from eye contact, etc., down to the one born from mental contact. With this the text explains only the divisions of sensation [as to types] for those students who at this time are uncertain as to the number of the subdivisions, but the nature of sensation is not explained, because it was alredy explained before. It was stated that eye consciousness arises depending on visual organ and its material object; these three come together and coexist, from this arises sensation born from eye contact. And this [sensation] is of three kinds. Pleasurable sensation is agreeable in the sense that it agrees with the sense faculties and gross matter. Painful sensation is disagreeable in the sense that it clashes with the relevant gross matter.” Cp. SN IV.216 (below) and AKoś VI.3 (below).

MN I.293 (1.5.3. Sutta 43. Mahāvedalla) Vedanā vedanāti āvuso vuccati. Kittāvatā nu kho āvuso vedanāti vuccatī"ti. Vedeti vedetīti kho āvuso, tasmā vedanāti vuccati kiñca vedeti?. Sukhampi vedeti, dukkhampi vedeti, adukkhamasukhampi vedeti. Vedeti vedetīti kho āvuso, tasmā vedanāti vuccatīti. "Saññā saññāti āvuso vuccati kittāvatā nu kho āvuso saññāti vuccatī"ti? Sañjānāti sañjānātīti kho āvuso, tasmā saññāti vuccati. Kiñca sañjānāti? Nīlakampi sañjānāti, pītakampi sañjānāti, lohitakampi sañjānāti, odātampi sañjānāti, sañjānāti sañjānātīti kho āvuso, tasmā saññāti vuccati. Yā cāvuso vedanā yā ca saññā yañca viññāṇaṃ ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā udāhu visaṃsaṭṭhā, labbhā ca panimesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetu"nti? Yā cāvuso vedanā yā ca saññā yañca viññāṇaṃ ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā no visaṃsaṭṭhā. Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetuṃ. Yañcāvuso vedeti taṃ sañjānāti, yaṃ sañjānāti taṃ vijānāti, tasmā ime dhammā sasaṃṭṭhā no visaṃsaṭṭhā. Na ca labbhā imesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetunti. “It is often said, Venerable, ‘sensation, sensation.’ Now, in what sense, Venerable, does one say ‘sensation’?” “It senses, insofar as it senses, Venerable, therefore one says, ‘sensation’. What does it sense? It senses what is pleasant, what is painful, and what is neither painful nor pleasant. . . ” “It is often said, Venerable, ‘forming an idea, forming an idea’. Now, in what sense, Venerable, does one say, ‘forming an idea’?”“ It forms an idea, insofar as it forms an idea, Venerable, therefore one says, ‘forming an idea.’ Of what does it form an idea? It forms an idea of blue, yellow, red, white. . . .” “sensation, ideation, and recognition (viññāṇa), Venerable, are these states and processes conjoined or disjoined? Is it possible to distinguish one from the other and to discern a difference among them?” “Sensation, ideation, and recognition, Venerable, occur in association with each other, not separately. It is not possible to distinguish one from the other and to discern a difference among them. For what one senses, one forms into an idea. What one forms into an idea, one recognizes. . . .” Cp. the translations of Thanissaro 2006-2012 and Nanamoli & Bodhi 1995.

SN IV.216 (4. Saḷāyatana 2.2.1.259) Tisso imā, bhikkhu, vedanā vuttā mayā. Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā . . . Vuttaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā – ‘yaṃ kiñci vedayitaṃ, taṃ dukkhasmin’ti. Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhārānaṃyeva aniccataṃ sandhāya bhāsitaṃ – ‘yaṃ kiñci vedayitaṃ taṃ dukkhasmi’nti . Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhārānaṃyeva khayadhammataṃ…pe… vayadhammataṃ…pe… virāgadhammataṃ …pe… nirodhadhammataṃ…pe… vipariṇāmadhammataṃ sandhāya bhāsitaṃ – ‘yaṃ kiñci vedayitaṃ taṃ dukkhasmi’nti. “I have spoken, monk, of these three kinds of sensations: pleasant sensations, unpleasant sensations, and sensations that are neither pleasant nor unpleasant. . . . But I have also said, monk, that ‘whatever is sensed is included in suffering’. Speaking by implication of the impermanence of things conditioned, I have said: ‘whatever is sensed is included in suffering’. Furthermore, speaking by implication of the dissolution of things conditioned, I have said: ‘whatever is sensed is included in suffering’. Speaking by implication of the disappearance of things conditioned, . . . of the fading away of things conditions, . . . of the ceasing of things conditioned, . . . of conditioned things being subject to change, I have said: ‘whatever is sensed is included in suffering’.” Cp. the translation of Bhikkhu Bodhi 2000; and AvinN 127 (abhiprāya for sandhāya). Also cp. AKoś VI.3, AKośBh (Pradhan 1975) 328-333 (LVP Tome II, pp. 124-139), and PratV (Tucci, JRAS, 1930, 615-616) = Dg 3995,33b6 -36a7), Frauwallner 1956, 43-49.

vedanā is a fem. form of the -ana proc. prod. noun (attested as nt.: vedana) from the root √vid-, IE *ṷeid- / *ṷoid-, “to see,” and in its perfective forms, “to know.” The root includes two semantic fields: to see (as in Latin videre) and to find, attain, acquire (as in Av. vīnastī). The second field can extend to meanings such as “to exist” or be present in one place (“there is,” as in Skt. vidyate). In this meaning it had an infixed present in IA (Av. *vinad-/viṇd-, Ved. vinda-). A third field, to experience, perhaps “to sense the presence of” is already found in Vedic and Brāhmaṇic literature, and is attested in OIr -fin-nadar. Turner (s.v. vēdanāˊ 12106) lists several derivatives in which the dominant referent is painful sensation. Cp. also the range of nirveda / nirvedana. Cp. PTSD s.v. vedeti: “For the present tense two bases are to be distinguished, viz. ved-, used in both meanings; and vediy- (=*vedy-), a specific Pāli formation after the manner of the 4th (y) class of Skt. verbs, used only in meaning of "experience." Thus vedeti: (a) to know (as=acc., equal to "to call") Sn 211 sq. (taṃ muniṃ vedayanti); (b) to feel, to experience SN IV.68 (phuṭṭho vedeti, ceteti, sañ<-> jānāti); MN I.37; Pv IV.150 (dukkhaṃ=anubhavati PvA 241). -vediyati: to feel, to experience a sensation or feeling (usually with vedanaṃ or pl. vedanā) MN I.59.”

vedanā ca hidaṃ mahāli, ekantadukkhaṃ abhavissa dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā, anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā vedanāya sārajjeyyuṃ, yasmā ca kho mahāli, vedanā sukhā sukhānupatitā, anavakkantā dukkhena tasmā sattā vedanāya sārajjanti, sārāgā saṃyujjanti, saṃyogā saṃkilissanti. ayampi kho mahāli, hetu ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṃkilesāya, evampi sahetu sappaccayā sattā saṃkilissanti.

div.p: BR considers the fem. form a Buddhist usage, listing under the nt. in CSkt. the meanings of “painful feeling,” and “pain,” as well as a more general sense of “knowing and perceiving.” As an adj. and a nt. noun, BR traces vedana, to the semantic field of “finding,” from which are derived CSkt. meanings such as “to obtain; assets, property, goods,” and, as an adj., “finding, procuring.” MW expands the field somewhat, noting: "making known, proclaiming." {For the meaning “pain, suffering,” see also IndSprüche 936ab: janmamṛtyujarāvyādhivedanābhir abhidrutam}

PTSD also notes as a second meaning, “(in special application) painful sensation, suffering, pain (i. e. dukkhavedanā) MN I.59; AN I.153 (sārīrikā bodily pain); II.116 (id.),” etc. This meaning of vedanā appears to contrast with Pāli “veda [fr. vid, or more specifically ved as P. root] . . . (joyful) feeling, religious feeling, enthusiasm, awe, emotion, excitement (something like saṃvega) DN II.210 (-paṭilābha+somanassa-paṭilābha); MN I.465 (uḍāra); Sn 1027 (= pīti SnA 585),” etc. PTSD also notes the five vedanās in Vism 461: sukhaṃ, dukkhaṃ, somanassaṃ, domanassaṃ, upekkhā.

Edgerton, BHSD also notes the meaning “painful sensation” in vedanā-bhinna “one oppressed by painful sensations MSV III.67.” Under vedaka, Edg distinguishes the meanings of one who knows and one who experiences of feels (the result of action), quoting, inter alia, Lv 419, na ca kārako ’sti tatha naiva ca vedako, and noting that the expression appears in “normal Skt” with “bhoktar contrasting with kartar.” BHSD also refers to the pairing of rāga with pleasant sensations, dveṣa (or doṣa) with unpleasant or painful sensations, and moha with neutral sensations (Śikṣ 232).

Despite its strict technical definition, vedanā constitutes both the superordinate class (the hypernym “sensation”) and a subordinate class (the hyponym “painful sensation”). It does not seem that this is a simple artifact of the world-view expressed in the stronger interpretations of the idea that suffering is inherent to the human condition (as in AKośBh VI.3).
